metadata.name: Kinetograms #85
metadata.description:
Each Kinetogram traces the movement of a number of simple shapes constrained within a single cell or a grid of cells. Forces are applied to the shapes in the form of attraction, gravity or shaking.

Some Kinetograms are partially or completely reflected, vertically or horizontally, some with chromatic replacement.

The aspect ratio is 3:4. The palettes are predominantly based on found textile patterns.

Press 's' to save a png image. Press 'e' to redraw and export a 4K png image. Note that drawing and physical simulation takes some time.

For interactive use, press 't' to tilt the board and 'c' to clear the board.

Written in p5.js with 2D physical simulation using Matter.js. Developed in and optimized for Chrome.

metadata.name: ZOOM (4hwf) #44
metadata.description:
"Das System lässt keine Überraschung zu. Überraschung ist Ausdruck partieller Unkenntnis. Überraschung weist auf Mangel von Wissen hin, deutet Leerstellen an. Bisher hatten sie keine Leerstellen festgestellt." — Herbert W. Franke

ZOOM explores linear scaling of pixels by zooming into a noisy framebuffer. Various zoom levels are composed one below the other, becoming a cinematic animation through iteration of the hue values of the pixels in the framebuffer.

In Gedenken an Herbert W. Franke
Kim Asendorf, 2022

metadata.name: Encoder #90
metadata.description:
Sketched studies using dithering algorithms and Worley noise patterns. Varying arrangements of background lines, points, and foreground marks combine to represent compositions from minimal to very complex. 

Viewing in desktop Chrome is recommended for the best results.
Press ’s’ to save a screenshot. Image size is 2318x3000px

Copyright (c) 2022 Matt Perkins, hello@mattperkins.me, @nudoru on Twitter. Licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 4.0, see LICENSE.txt for more information.

metadata.name: Liquid Metal #62
metadata.description: This animated artwork contains a series of circular forms that have a liquid ripple effect.  The forms move across the canvas like water droplets on a rainy windshield. The forms also mimic microscopic cellular organisms as they shift and morph in an organic manner. Sometimes a bulbous 3 dimensional shape is formed around the ripple droplets when the system overloaded feature is activated.

metadata.name: tratti #103
metadata.description:
"tratti" is an Italian word that has many different meanings. When we started working on this piece, we wanted to create something that combines our traits ("tratti" in Italian).
We had this urge to channel the turbulent times we're living in now into this artwork using just lines ("tratti" in Italian).

We don't know what to do now, we're here, and that's all that matters. We're here for our families, our friends, and our community. Like everything in life, there are joyful times and challenging times. We must accept happiness as something that is not constant but that we feel at times (a "tratti" in Italian).

With "tratti", we want to send a message to every disheartened human being: "Stay strong and never let anyone or anything crush the hope in you. Joyful times are around the corner".

---- 

© 2022 — Alessandro Fiore x Emanuele Pasin
LICENSE.md for detailed licensing info

metadata.name: Mines #3
metadata.description:
"He found himself wondering at times, especially in the autumn, about the wild lands, and strange visions of mountains that he had never seen came into his dreams"
- J.R.R. Tolkien

Mines is an exploration of these mountains of dreams, and the ancient mechanics that shape them. The work of eons, where the landscapes we know rise and fall like ocean waves.

To know them, we must go beneath the mountain.

---
- Made with p5js
- Press “s” to save png
- Use param ?width=x to render at specific width
- Use param ?bg=true to render on full color background (instead of the default dark background)

metadata.name: Separation in the Night #135
metadata.description:
For this project I was strongly inspired by the paintings of Mark Rothko, Jackson Pollock, Kazemir Malevich, but mostly token refers to the works of one of the largest figures of the European avant-garde, Paul Klee. I wanted to convey that complex color mood and atmosphere that artist achieved with oil paints. 
I have been working with color palettes and functions for a long time to make complex transitions and gradients. This code has really huge potential for a wide diversity of artworks and I would like to see as many interesting variations as possible. Enjoy<3

Project contains:

•three canvas types : horizontal, vertical, square
•rare features : vertical stripes, posterization
•press "p" to pause animation and play again
•open in tab and press "s" to save .png


Made in P5.js by @Georginerous

metadata.name: Minima #92
metadata.description:
Minima is a study on focus and color. Playing with the idea of a simple composition of semicircles, either rotated up or down. The focus of the observer is moved with the use of gradual animation in the gradients and occasional circles and/or rectangles connecting the shapes together through color.

The name minima stems from the origins of the composition, mostly taking inspiration from minimalism in its use of a few elements to form a composition greater than the sum of its parts. Less is more, as they say.

The point at the bottom right of the canvas resembles the end of a sentence. Like reading a book, you process the canvas in a similar way, moving from what pops the most to what the least.

As the reader of this canvas I hope you observe what happens to your focus as the colors gradually move across the screen. The animations themselves are looping based on a noised sine wave, which gives them imperfections, imperfections you can observe.

----

Click / Tap on the bar at the bottom of the canvas to open up the GUI, used to export your minima into any format you want. Either .png or .svg. Ready for printing, if you desire.

ps. there might be a secret keyboard shortcut...

----

Minima,
Wouter Missler, 2022,
p5js + webgl.

metadata.name: Évasion #75
metadata.description:
This project is inspired by a familiar landscape.
 
It combines several things: a realistic dune landscape, minimalist ocean and sky, and a surrealist window at the centre.

The window deliberately presents a brighter ocean, where the sun is reflected, with waves and veils caught in the wind. It aims at representing what inspires us, what calms us, what makes us feel at home. This window extracts us from our daily thoughts and stress.


So I named this project "Évasion", a French word, which could be translated as "Escape" in English.


In this project, I decided that, even though each output will be unique and will have its own features, it will be possible, in live mode, to show/hide some elements of the project. This will allow each one of you to adapt the project to what is most relevant to you and save it.

This does not change the unique features of your mint, but you can adapt it to your preferences, to what "Évasion" means to you.



Consequently, in live mode, multiple options are available.

You can display the output with different pixel densities for a better resolution:

 - press [2] to display a 2000 x 2000 pixels output (display by default)
 - press [3] to display a 3000 x 3000 pixels output
 - press [4] to display a 4000 x 4000 pixels output (may take a moment)


You can also toggle different elements of the output, even though these features are not part of your mint:

 - press [d] to toggle the visibility of the dune
 - press [v] to toggle the visibility of the veils
 - press [t] to toggle the visibility of the sun texture
 - press [w] to toggle the visibility of the window shadow
 - press [a] to toggle the visibility of the sun rays
 - press [r] to reload


To save the output as it is displayed:

 - press [s] on a computer
 - double tap on a mobile device


On the contrary, some elements cannot be changed, such as the color palette, the place of the window and sun, the appearence of the dune, the texture, the format, etc.


Main features of this project include:

- Palette: 9 color palettes,
- Margin: Thin or Large,
- Texture: None, Soft or Strong,
- Format: 1:1, 4:5 - Portrait or 4:5 - Landscape,
- Veils: True or False,
- Rays: True or False,
- Sun Texture: True or False.


Thank you so much to all the collectors <3


Created with p5.js

metadata.name: Hope #487
metadata.description:
Ups, downs, and everything in between. This series is about prevailing hope in the journey of life.
Each brush stroke is meant to elicit perspective, connectivity, beauty, and hope.

Features:
F  -  Fullscreen
S  -  Save image
2/4/6/8/0  -  Change image resolution (press number key and then reload in live view, please wait a few seconds for higher resolutions to load)

Designed in p5js
Original artwork, 2022 by fauxjebus and Dave Siegel

“To live without hope is to cease to live.”
- Fyodor Dostoyevsky

metadata.name: CENTURY-XXX-METAFRANKE #807
metadata.description:
1 of 5 in CENTURY-XXX, Series 2
Edition of 1000

Tribute to Herbert W. Franke
“In Honor of the Dinosaur of Computer Art” 

Herbert W. Franke, a pioneer of computer art, passed away on July 16, 2022 at the age of 95. CENTURY-XXX-METAFRANKE is an homage to Franke’s MONDRIAN software developed for the Texas Instruments TI 99/4 home computer in 1979, and it’s a fundraiser to digitize his archive:

“Our goal is to raise 20,000 Euro so that ZKM Karlsruhe can digitize Herbert W. Franke’s 1,800 manuscripts and make them publicly available. If we raise more money, it will be donated to the Rütgers Foundation which supports children and young adults in Africa so that they can get access to and work with technology.” 

Each frame, a single “pixel” is added to the CENTURY-XXX-METAFRANKE image. When the software first loads, 100,000 frames are run in the background to start things off. Keep it running for hours or days to see it transform entirely — it’s an “infinite animation.”
